text: (calm electronic music) (keyboard clacking)

- [Voiceover] Welcome to
the "AWS for AI Podcast."

- Welcome to "AWS for AI," the podcast where we explore
cutting-edge AI solutions
and the innovators behind them. I'm your host, Hamza Mimi, solution architect at AWS,

and today I'm thrilled to
welcome Phillip Kingston, chief technology officer at AppliedAI.

Phillip brings a unique combination of technical innovation
and entrepreneurial vision to our conversation.

With over two decades
in tech as a founder, CEO, and CTO across financial services,
cybersecurity, and AI, Phillip has built an impressive career developing breakthrough technologies
that solve complex business challenges. In his role as CTO of AppliedAI, he's leading the development of Opus,

the world's first large work model, that's reimagining the whole
agentic workflow architecture.

While large language models
predict the next word, Opus, and large work models,

predicts the next action. Phillip and AppliedAI
have recently published
fascinating research demonstrating how Opus is able to understand workflow intentions

and integrates multimodal inputs
with work knowledge graphs to create more effective,

auditable, and optimized workflow and, overall, optimize the
business processes in a way

that's significantly outperforming
conventional approaches. Phillip, it's a pleasure
to have you with us today.

Welcome to the show.
- Thank you, Hamza. - Thank you very much, Hamza, great to meet you and great to be here. - Let me start with your personal journey.
What brought you to join AppliedAI here in the UAE?
- Yeah, thank you. So, my personal journey, as you've said, I've spent many years looking at startups

from the perspective of
regulated industries. So I've always been fascinated with technology adoption and absorption

inside the enterprise, which has unique challenges compared to more
consumer-facing technology.

So, post-COVID, like a lot of people, was thinking about kind of what's next. The impact that that had
on the world was profound.
And I was sitting in Australia, I was born in Melbourne, in the South of Australia. - A real Aussie.
- Real Aussie, that's right. And I got a call out of the blue late 2021

from a friend of mine, Arya Molurfrushan, that I'd known for many years. Business endeavors that
had taken me to New York
and parts of the U.S., where I met Arya and became good friends, probably over 15 years.
And so I got a call from him, and he was telling me what he was doing in artificial intelligence.

And the whole problem
space that he had defined and the opportunity that he was pursuing was extremely ambitious.
It involved regulated industries and cutting-edge technology. So I was deeply fascinated.

So I was following the journey
from afar from Melbourne. And eventually I would sort of,

I started advising the
business a few days a week and then became full-time,
moved to the UAE in late 2022 and haven't looked back.
It's a big change. It's a bit different to Melbourne. But now coming up to three years.
Very, very pleased that I made the move to be part of an extremely rare moment,

the rise of a new
technology power in the UAE. And yeah, based in Abu Dhabi.

We now live in Yas Island, which is just an incredible
part of the world.

- Absolutely amazing.
- So, very, very pleased I made the move. - So this was before
the generative AI era.
What was the attracting thing that brought you actually in, what Arya told you?
Is it the regulated industry, the challenge, the AI part? - Well, I think, I mean,
a whole lot of factors made it appealing. The scale of the ambition, obviously.

That even pre generative AI, the sort of ChatGPT/OpenAI
moment of late 2022

that really changed, I suppose, the public
consciousness of what was happening for many years beforehand

was a catalyst, of course. But yes, this was all pre sort of the public
understanding of the LLM.

And I think the ambition was
really looking at why is it that large organizations struggle
to adopt technology still.

And given the significance of AI, as profound on productivity
as electricity,

as the wheel and fire, we're talking about a
foundational moment in history,

how was an organization or a
government organization going to consume artificial intelligence?
Not at the individual user level, not at, say, the data science teams or the sort of, you know,
technology part of the organizations, but holistically, whether the organization is the customer,
is the user, as opposed to, you know, users using AI
to make their own productivity greater. And it's quite a different conversation

getting sort of an artificial
intelligence solution to the point where the
organization can govern it,
adopt it everywhere holistically, and understand it, have it be auditable, explainable,
keeping all the decision points, you know, immutably forever. - Absolutely.

- And what is unique
about regulated industries and why we sort of go on about this is that the fundamental difference

with a regulated organization
is that the process, the procedure,
is often as important, often more important than the outcome.

And so there's a sort of
general division in the world about goal-seeking AI

that gets the right answer
as quickly as possible. That sort of wow, magic moment of okay, wow, how did you know that?
That's great, that's amazing. And the procedural inherent nature of the requirements of an organization,
which is, we need to do this process the same way, every single time, no exceptions.

- Yeah, absolutely. And I can relate that to the diffusion of innovation
theory from Everett Rogers,

where you're working in the area where you need to actually get to that early adopters
majority and bypass that chasm.

- Yes.
- In related industry. That's probably something
that you see every day
with your customers. - Yeah, there's, I suppose, a tension between speed of adoption,
top-down pressure. We need to be doing something in AI, what's our AI plan? What's our AI strategy?

And, you know, this will
be a perpetual discussion as the capabilities improve,

the scope of business functions that can be improved
grows and grows over time.
This is not like a, you know, one-moment-in-time situation where these questions are being asked.

I think a lot of knowledge
work is up for grabs in terms of how it's performed,
what share of the work is done by a system versus a human. And the default position now
and starting in sort of 2025 timeline is what percentage is done by human and AI,

which is, you know, a profoundly different
position than three years ago, which is, can AI do any of this stuff?

And then, you know, three years from now, we'll probably be asking
different questions. - Absolutely.

Just to touch on your
personal story again. You're the CTO of AppliedAI,
but you're also doing research work. You're a professor of AI. How do you balance with the current state,
where you need to learn about the AI technology and apply it, and the operational work as a CTO

of a startup that's becoming
actually a multinational now? - Yeah, I mean, it's a difficult one.

What's unique about, I think, AI as a manager compared
to regular software

is the deterministic versus
probabilistic nature of things. So most software people,

they know what a bug is. They know that there are
problems in the system. But when you press run,

your code will do, you know, more or less the same
thing every single time. There are edge cases,

there are problems in design and problems in execution for sure, but the core of the software
is a deterministic beast.

And the people that have
grown up around software, who write software for a living, who work in the software industry,

are very much, like,
deterministic in their mindset. And the level of theory
that permeates their work
is typically related to algorithms and computer-science-type issues that are still deterministic in nature.

What's different about
sort of bleeding edge, state-of-the-art artificial
intelligence work and, in fact, all new blended
areas of software and AI
is products which may have started as a transformer architecture model are becoming holistic software solutions,

doing many, many more things
than just a model inference. What's unique about this challenge is you have to blend theory
and kind of fairly high-order mathematics with a lot of probability and statistics

that's fundamentally not deterministic. And the sorts of people
that have grown up around
and are experienced in this world generally are different types of animals

to the people that work
in pure play software. And so, a academic research organization
and a sort of fast-paced software culture is a difficult thing to put together,

but it's one of the things that is necessary in a
modern AI organization. And we're fortunate enough
to have some very experienced researchers and innovative young people,

you know, looking at
things with fresh eyes across the whole problem space of knowledge work completion,

where you have these constraints of process and procedural adherence. And so most of our
research work is in trying
to represent a workflow mathematically in a robust way that scales
to the sort of corpus of knowledge work in large organizations,

but we have to be able to
instantiate this as software that, you know, you can deploy

and you can deal with with
all sorts of security,
access control, governance, and all the data elements that also is a relatively new field.
So the use of data was a problem obviously tackled from a storage

and cloud infrastructure
kind of standpoint since the birth of, you know,

any kind of internet connectivity. But now with the new uses
of data around training,
validation, drift, all the sort of ongoing model assessments, these kind of things,
the different user groups, the amount of user groups that sit around the data conversation now

is significantly higher
than it used to be. And so it is really a
three-party conversation.
There's the software piece, the AI theory and research piece, and the data governance controls
and cyber and operational security piece, which is equally important,
and there's just tension everywhere. And the ambition of what people want, the practicalities of doing it,

and working around all
those constraints makes for a fascinating internal team culture, but also with client
deployments and client adoption,
all those conversations are happening in really all businesses around the world. Those trade-offs between what can be done,
what we'd like to be able to do, and, you know, the necessary constraints that are placed on those businesses
by the regulations that are imposed. - And I can imagine those would take

fascinating day-to-day schedules
as well from your side. - Yes. - Let's touch to some extent
to AppliedAI's vision.

What's the mission behind AppliedAI? You've already touched
on Arya's initial vision,

but what's the company's mission and some of the current work
that you're touching on?

- Yeah, so, I think the AI opportunity is
still in its infancy.

And some of the questions
that we're trying to tackle with software solutions is,

how does a modern organization
consume human labor? So, going from the default
to the blended labor supply model, where AI's doing a part of the work, humans are doing a part of the work.

This is an extremely important
distinction in goal function. We are not trying to replace humans.

And notice I unitize the
conversation on work completion. It's not about having
less humans, more humans,
it's about saying, per unit of work, and opus is Latin for work, and it has beautiful deployments in music

and other, you know, historic moments where opus is a term which
has just great associations
that we draw upon for naming products and naming parts of our ecosystem, which we'll come back to,

it's really looking at the
future of work and saying, what is, as a goal function,

the best way to use humans
based on their capabilities? And what is the best ways to
use AI with its capabilities?
And each have constraints. Some need sleep, some don't need sleep.

Some get tired, some don't. The ways in which they
can deal with uncertainty,
policy discovery, edge cases, you know, is different. So it's sort of almost like
a discussion about compromise and building the best team

of work deployment and
delivery capabilities. And this makes

the software design principles
a little bit different, because it's not saying
have a human review

when the work is done, and that's a naive and not
a bad first approximation. But a much better way
to think about this is,

what are all the points that we have to get right in a workflow such that the total cost of
human input is minimized,

the overall productivity of
the workflow is maximized, but noting that AI is
also not free, right?

There's compute, there's inference, there's a whole lot of
energy infrastructure that sits around it, that doesn't go away.

So it's about where are
all the right places to put the humans and the AI against these cost functions.
- So, to just go a level deeper into the idea about not replacing humans
but enhancing their capabilities, is this a technical constraint,
that we're not able to replace humans, or do you think that, at some point,

there is a deeper
philosophical perspective where we actually need humans in the loop?

- I think the answer is both. There's certain areas where the sort of
sociotechnological intersection
is hard to model, like autopilots in civilian aviation.

Most people accept that AI is capable of doing
all the things it needs to be able to do to fly a plane,

but we still have pilots. And we're likely to have
pilots for some time. However, the same technical
challenge of driving a train,

say, between airport terminals, people are very happy for
the intra-terminal train
to be self-driving with no human supervision. - I love the image there.

We're building very sophisticated planes that are capable of doing everything, but we still need that pilot
to actually drive everything

and make sure that it still works. - That's right, and humans are probably
irrational in this regard.

There's no, you know,
sort of intrinsic safety or probability argument that will defend why we're comfortable
with full automation here and not there. And that's okay, we don't have to solve that.

But I think it's about identifying where does an organizational
risk profile sit.

And not all work in an
organization is created equal. We are an enterprise artificial
intelligence company,
we have different standards because we're trying to work within regulated industry constraints.
But for a consumer application where you just want, you know, a good restaurant recommendation

or you want something to be summarized just to save you time in
doing some quick research

on something you're interested in, it just doesn't matter as much. So, we also think that
that human acceptance

of AI as the leader and potentially, you
know, fully unsupervised,
that the aperture of acceptance of that is gonna grow dramatically over time.

So what we now think is
acceptable for an AI to do, I think, will change.

- Just want to go back to
AppliedAI as a company. For those watching us

that don't know about
AppliedAI as a company, what can you tell them
about where it started,

where it is now, and what are you seeing
in the near future? - Absolutely.

So we started in late 2021, solving what we would now
call vertical AI solutions.
At that time, domain-specific models generally outperformed general models.

And you would do things
like pre-train a model, not fine-tune but actually
train on a domain,
around a very specific need. And, you know, 9 times out of 10,

that would be a better
result than a general model. Now, this has changed in late 2022.
And so the, I suppose, market conditions

on the demand side have
started asking questions about, well, if general models are very good,

why don't we have general
products and platform solutions? And I suppose some latency
in the VC and capital markets

that still believe that
vertical solutions are the,
you know, the best answer, which is a relic of the SaaS world. But, you know,

AWS, for example, is a cloud infrastructure
solution for all industries. You don't say, "Oh, we don't do,

you know, we don't do this, we only do that," right? You say, "Well, anything that we can
support with our capability
is an industry we can work with." So we started in healthcare doing,

first product was called DeepDoc. And it was about assisting
independent medical evaluations,

where, in a contested insurance claim, you would have, someone
would make a claim to say,
"I've been injured at work, here are my injuries, this is the hospital care that I received,

and I wanna claim that on
my workers' compensation." Now, a certain percentage of the time, the insurer will say,
"That's fine, here it is. Paid, done." Other percentage of the time, they'll say, "No, this injury didn't happen at work,"

or, "You were over-serviced, you didn't need all of this, you got some other procedure
done at the same time
that isn't covered," this kind of thing. And so sometimes there's conflict around whether a claim should be paid.

And so this industry is
called claims adjustment, generally, globally. So we built solutions
to review large amounts
of claim documentation. Often, a contested claim is one which has gone on for some time.

Maybe an injury's taken
a long time to recover. And maybe there's been
litigation in the past

or some legal contest in the past. So you'll have a lot of documents. Thousands, tens of thousands
of pages of material.

And the people that can review that to make insurance decisions
are expensive, usually.

So we have a high cost of labor, and we need to summarize
and organize that material in a way that's easy for them to consume,

to effectively make claims
adjustment decisions in a very, very short amount of time.

And this industry also
values independence, because before anyone litigates
around insurance claims,

both sides will obtain a medical expert who will give a sense of
the different perspectives

that a judge or a jury might take on a particular claim context. So having an independent
AI assessment to say,

"Well, I've looked at all
the materials with no agenda, I'm not on anyone's side, and this is what I think
is the medical basis

of this claim," that's also valuable
as an independent voice in decision-making on both sides.

So this solution is used
by plaintiff attorneys and potential plaintiffs to evaluate the probability of success

and some of the key medical issues. And it's used on the defense for the insurance company side to say, "Well, should we pay or
defend this claim or settle?"

So, that's where we started. And we moved into a range
of other deeply niche and boring problems like this,
where they're regulated, they have high stakes, mission-critical decisions.
So there's a high cost of error, what we say, what is the cost of error? And we try to focus on use cases

that have a high cost of error, 'cause that's usually where there's a high willingness to pay and also high cost of
existing incumbent labor.

So the business case makes a lot of sense because there's a lot of money in play. If you can save someone's
time who's expensive,

then obviously there are
high business outcomes. So another example just for completeness

is we went into the
pharmaceutical industry, where we wanted to look at, you know, in clinical trials,

drugs that make it through
ultimately get licensed by certain drug regulators. And once they're licensed,

there's a whole new regime
of oversight that starts that's typically referred
to as pharmacovigilance.

And it's a largely self-reported regime where pharmaceutical
companies need to monitor all of the drugs that are licensed

that they've produced to make sure that those drugs
are adequately described

on their packaging and their labels, that the medical industry is
using them in the right way. And that if there's, for example,

a new side effect that's emerging maybe that didn't show up in trials because of, you know, some
diversity that was missed

or other drug combinations
that were missed, then that can be captured. And the industry can then adapt to say,

"Well, we need to put
an extra warning label." You know, don't take while pregnant or don't take while
operating heavy machinery

or something like this. And update the warning label
to provide more information, update the medical education
provided to the pharmacists

and the physicians that are
prescribing these drugs. And so, as you can imagine, there is an enormous amount of
literature produced every day

on side effect reports, on medical studies at universities, on public health bodies that
are producing science often,

or at least medical case studies
that need to be reviewed. So this is an enormous amount

of material to consume globally. And we cover all countries,
all major languages.

So we consume this and we
find insights that say, "Well, there is a
pattern emerging in Japan

where this combination of
drugs is causing this issue." You know, and then we can work with the companies that make those drugs
to decide on sort of what happens next. So, you know, that was our second domain,
which we call Covigilance, is our product, and that's become a huge success for us. But this is our legacy.

We see this as a happy
moment between 2021 and 2024, but we've totally changed our model now

with the birth of Opus. - So, you've been, and you touched on the
healthcare industry in general,

pharmaceutical, you've also worked in finance and banking, with what you now refer
to as legacy solutions.

- Yes. - What are some of the challenges that you've seen in highly
regulated industries
importing new technologies in general? And AI in particular, this is a regular discussion we're having

with AWS customers as well. What are the expectations
that you're hearing

from your customers in
highly regulated industries to get those first solutions implemented?
- Yeah, there's a whole range of issues that are faced by decision makers

in regulated enterprises. One of the sort of other side
of the coin of the vertical,

our legacy, say, product suite and the way a lot of people
approach this problem over the sort of 2021, 2022 period
is you end up with point solutions, where an organization is buying good AI

but from a lot of vendors. And so as AI increases
its sphere of influence

on the types of knowledge
work that it can help. The conclusion is a
lot of point solutions,

and this is something
that creates a lot of risk and a lot of costs. And what we found with studying

other adoption cycles of technology, for example, the major system
of record companies tend

to have a lot of consolidation
within an organization. So you don't wanna have a
lot of systems of record
if you can avoid it, you typically want one or a small number of systems of record.

And we think this is
what's happening right now in the enterprise AI industry, where people have done a
lot of proof of concepts,

they've got some great point solutions, but the conversations that we're having at the director level,
the executive level is,

"I don't wanna have
500 AI point solutions. I can't govern this, I can't manage this."
Each one wants to get, you know, access to data warehouses, they wanna get access to,
you know, compute infrastructure maybe for fine-tuning on specific, you know, organizational data.

We just can't govern this. - And, you know, there's a whole cybersecurity
conversation as well
around having too many things, it's risky. So, we think that the platform approach
is the right approach, but it's a big ask of an organization

to adopt a platform in
the early days of AI, where things are still
changing so quickly.
So what we've... I think the answer is to be able to start with a point solution,
prove value, prove capability, and then be able to effectively back
into a platform solution. So saying that another way, having the point solution,
which takes risk off the table, as one workflow

on a system that can deploy thousands or hundreds of thousands of
workflows for that organization.

- Okay. So, your vision is we're moving out from
the vertical solutions
to horizontal solutions. And you've touched about, you touched a bit about

on the verticals that
you've been working on, legacy and now moving to Opus.
What can you tell us about the challenge that poses using horizontal solutions now,

and the Opus as an example, the Opus platform that's basically answering
multiple use cases

in the same platform? - Yeah, so there's opportunity
and there's complexity. So, the opportunity is,

if you build an integration
to a system of record, it's reusable, generally. So you go through all the effort
of doing the data governance lift, getting everyone's approvals, doing the integration.

But now that unlocks value for many different users
across the organization.

And interdisciplinary
work is another reason that motivates a horizontal solution,

because sometimes you'll have a document or a workflow that is only
worked on by one skillset.

So it might be a legal document where, top to bottom, it's only
lawyers looking at that. It's only in the legal department, no one else cares.
They do exist, but that's probably rarer than workflows that actually interrelate

or at least involve other disciplines. Maybe we need accounting,
maybe we need audit, maybe we need marketing or design.

So, any workflow which is working across
disciplines in an organization

is something that a vertical
solution will struggle with.

And the other thing, on the supply side, so I've been talking a
lot about demand side, the challenges on the enterprise,

but you've gotta look at the supply side. The majority of our competition
is not AI companies,

it's business process
outsourcing companies. It's the, you know, the sort of tail end of
the private equity era,
where it was extremely sensible in the 80s, 90s, and 2000s

to outsource work that was repetitive, that could be codified to markets that had lower
average cost of labor,

time zone advantages, lower cost of living, et cetera. You could basically create
financial performance

by doing it the same way, just in a different place. And this was an extremely
successful period

that the internet enabled with email and then more
sophisticated solutions to actually pass this work around.
And they would follow the sun, it also enabled lower costs. Now, they are,

the BPO companies are the
biggest competitor right now
to platform AI adoption because they don't say no,

generally, to new work. If a client says, "Hey,
you're currently doing this, this, and this for us, can you also do this?"
Any sensible BPO would say, "Absolutely, we'd do that. When can we start?" And when you're in the vertical add,

you're saying, "Well, we don't do that." And to spin up engineering and product to pivot or take that
on is an enormous lift.

- So, this is still a
very active discussion about the horizontal versus the vertical

and still having the vision from some of the vertical builders about specific solutions
that they still think

that are the best way forward, and you mentioned about
some of these use cases. But you also make a distinction
between solutions versus platforms. So what's the distinctions here

between a solution and a platform? - Different people will have
different views on this. The way I look at it is

who's in charge of the
scope of the software. So in a platform solution,

the user and the
organization is sort of free to decide what it does and doesn't do,

you know, adjust not just
settings within a solution, like, you know, maybe temperature of a model
or something like this,

but actually design sort of
the whole application logic. And I think, you know,
the sort of product land is typically more focused on, they will preordain the value proposition

and have a much more certain outcome, but with a narrower sort
of scope of deployment.

- Excellent. You touched on the
enterprise AI new realm,

and I also want to move a
bit to talk about Opus now, which is your new platform
solution platform.
What do you think Opus is bringing that we are not able to have before that?

- Yeah. I mean, there's a lot
of things that we see as totally differentiated in what Opus is bringing to the table.

The first thing is on workflow generation. So, many people, when asked
to automate a process,
will recreate what they have now. And they'll do a good job of that.
And any RPA, like, robotic process automation tool or any workflow builder will allow you
to recreate the status quo. So add conditionals, if this, do this, add loops,
drop in an agent, drop in an LLM, drop in this. Like, this is par for the course, and there are great people that do that.
What we're trying to solve is, what is the AI impression of that work?
What is the new way of doing this that maybe leverages capabilities

that you may not fully understand, that leverages model
strengths and weaknesses that you may not understand,

that is also future-forward that is somehow evolving with
the underlying improvements?

So if a model vendor
introduces new capability, how do you stay current

without having to go through
an entire redesign process? So this whole discipline
of flexible design time,
where a workflow can be built with a whole lot of support from,

in our case, a work knowledge graph, which is a, you know,
hundred-million-node graph,
knowledge graph that we host in AWS, that stores every distilled,

documented process that
we've been able to find in sort of the world's literature
on knowledge work process.
So, we formalized what a workflow is,

we formalized what intention is, and we applied those
formalisms to the corpora

of documents globally. Everything that talks
about a business process,
we've codified, structured, interpreted into an Opus framework.
We store it in our knowledge graph and we use that with our large work model

to design workflows on the
fly with no business context
that represent two things. One, the sort of AI-inspired,

AI-era version of that workflow that will be cost-efficient,
highly accurate,
save the most amount of time, put human reviews in all the right places.
- So, Opus basically is trying to solve that complex organizational processes
that are sometimes well-defined, sometimes are less well-defined.

And I just want to dive a bit deeper on the technical aspects and some of the research
papers that you published.

So, you already touched
on the graph concept,

but you also define what
you call workflow intention.

Can you talk a bit about
what's a workflow intention in the Opus framework? - Yeah, so an intention to us is a triple

of input, process, and output. It's incredibly simple. It's telescopic, so it works at the
whole of workflow level.

So what do I want this workflow to do? What constitutes a good
workflow generation?

And this is really where
this formalism was required, because we'd both say, you know,
In Opus you can just write a prompt, you can describe it using a voice memo.

Basically, you can just
upload a picture of a process. We take a lot of inputs, it's a multimodal system.

So you throw at us some description that can be structured or
unstructured of a workflow, and then we will produce
as executable code

that can be deployed into
an enterprise environment. Within minutes, an end-to-end workflow that does what?
And the answer is it does your intention. What constitutes the right workflow

based on the information
you have given us? So we force a resolution
of the unstructured multimodal inputs into an intention object

but also, sometimes,
multiple intention objects. And so sometimes people
will describe something
that is much better suited as two workflows or five workflows.
Or it might be the other way, where actually the workflow is too simple. And to use our parlance,

it's actually just a
task inside a workflow. So we need to think
about workflow intention

to resolve working within
context window limits and a whole lot of technical limitations.

If a workflow is, say,
a whole of business, like, you know,
do a bank for me as a workflow, it's too big to really deal with
in the context of sort of one workflow. So there's an extreme side, but then there's also,

and this is where there's a
whole product solution space, is, something that's too
small to be a workflow,

which is something that
should be really just a task, like, "Summarize this document for me."
To us, that's a task. That's something that is valuable because it sits inside a broader process
